awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Leveraging Physical Side-Channel Information to Build Detection-Based Rowhammer Defenses
awd_abstract_narration:
Preventing a process from modifying a memory it does not own is a cornerstone of security.  However, this essential protection has recently come under threat due to the discovery of a vulnerability, known as the Rowhammer for dynamic random-access memory (DRAM). It has been found that this vulnerability commonly exists in DRAM chips and can be exploited to form a wide range of powerful attacks. Defending against Rowhammer attack remains a challenging problem. This project aims to solve this problem by developing novel detection-based defense techniques. 

The project has 3 major thrusts. Thrust 1 will analyze certain inevitable physical side effects of computation (e.g., electromagnetic radiation, acoustic emanation, and power consumption) to discover malicious hammering. Thrust 2 will design and implement deployable defense techniques based on the discovered physical side-channel information which can robustly detect and promptly thwart any potential Rowhammer attacks, including elusive ones hidden inside trusted execution environments. Thrust 3 concerns experiments and evaluation to  quantify and demonstrate the significance of the project. 

The techniques developed in this project may impact industry and help practitioners design more secure and dependable systems. 

Code, data, publications, presentations, will be released publicly. A project repository will be maintained on CPS-VO (https://cps-vo.org/) for at least 5 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While computer systems unavoidably emit rich physical side-channel information that attackers routinely exploit, this NSF SaTC Small project posed an inverse question: can these inevitable physical side effects be repurposed for detecting malicious activities? Specifically, this project targeted rowhammer, a fault-injection attack that allows unprivileged software to induce bit flips in memory and thereby subvert a system’s confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability. 

The objectives in this project were to investigate various types of physical side-channel information, analyze their security implications, and leverage the findings to design rowhammer detection systems. The project focused on three research areas: (1) investigating physical side-channel information emitted by modern computers; (2) designing detection-based rowhammer defenses; and (3) conducting experimentation and evaluation. 

The project accomplished the following key results: 

1. Advanced our understanding of how electromagnetic signals emanated by main memory and GPU memory can be exploited to leak sensitive information. 

2. Examined the security implications of power side-channels, particularly focusing on Intel RAPL-induced vulnerabilities. 

3. Discovered and characterized a previously unexplored physical side channel stemming from the mechanical movements of the CPU and power supply unit cooling fans. 

4. Developed a rowhammer detection method that leverages mmWave‑based monitoring of fan rotational speed to identify potential attacks.  

5. Evaluated the potential impact of rowhammer-induced faults on deep neural network models in various contexts. 

Key broader impact activities include: 

1. Dissemination and outreach. The project generated 18 papers published/accepted in journals, conferences, and workshops. Highlights of the publications include papers published at top-tier venues such as S&P, USENIX Security, CCS, MobiSys, and ECCV. 

2. Professional development. The project involved one graduate student, who completed his Ph.D. degree supported mainly by this project. 

3. Education. Material related to the project, including research topics and student projects, has been incorporated into a graduate-level course on hardware security and an undergraduate-level course on computer systems at Clemson University. 

4. Open-source software. Source code for many of our research artifacts is publicly available to foster further work on related topics. 

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2025
Modified by: Zhenkai Zhang
